page.title: 13Hubbards Hills
page.content: Perhaps the most famous place in Louth is Hubbards Hills.It is a valley carved out by meltwater streams during the last Ice age.In places it is 100 feet deep and it covers 14 hectares. During the 18 hundreds the valley and surrounding hills came into the possesion of Auguste Alphonse Pahud. He came from Switzerland to teach languages at King Edward IV Grammar School. His wife died suddenly and Pahud committed suicide leaving the hills to the people of Louth. Today the land is protected and is a favourite place for wildlife and recreation. Louth has a uniqe position on the Greenwich Meridian longitude line. In 1948 a plaque was erected on Eastgate to mark its position.Every day hundreds of people pass from East to West without realising it.
